<p>A chemical peel can exfoliate your skin, removing dead dry skin cells on the surface and leaving a softer, smoother complexion underneath. While many chemical peels are performed in a doctor's office, there are also home versions that use less potent chemicals. When you learn the proper way to prepare for and apply these products, you will see the best chemical peel results. However, chemical peels are more effective and safer when done by a professional – so proceed with caution.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 1" class="reference" id="_ref-1"><a href="#_note-1">[1]</a></sup></p>

<img alt="Image titled Apply a Chemical Peel Step 1" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0e/Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid1564435-v4-728px-Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-1-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_abdc601344" onload="WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_abdc601344')</script>

<noscript><img alt="Image titled Apply a Chemical Peel Step 1" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" onload="WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0e/Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-1-Version-3.jpg/aid1564435-v4-728px-Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-1-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript>
<script>WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');</script></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Buy from a reputable company with good reviews.</b> If possible, get a chemical peel kit from a spa or dermatologist’s office. If you shop online, be sure to check user reviews to see what customers are saying. Only buy a chemical peel from a reputable company with excellent user reviews.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 2" class="reference" id="_ref-2"><a href="#_note-2">[2]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Choose a product made in an FDA-regulated lab that is certified to be 99% pure or better.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 3" class="reference" id="_ref-3"><a href="#_note-3">[3]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>Make sure the product contains a phone number for customer service. You should be able to call and ask questions if you need to.</li>
</ul>
<script>WH.performance.mark('step1_rendered');</script>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-2-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=1564435" href="#/Image:Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-2-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Apply a Chemical Peel Step 2" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/75/Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-2-Version-3.jpg/aid1564435-v4-728px-Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-2-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_2b97e1d538" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_2b97e1d538')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Apply a Chemical Peel Step 2" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/75/Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-2-Version-3.jpg/aid1564435-v4-728px-Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-2-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Select the type of peel based on your needs.</b> Different chemical peels are better for different needs and skin types. Choose the right peel for you:<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 4" class="reference" id="_ref-4"><a href="#_note-4">[4]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>
<i>Glycolic acid peels</i>: improve acne, blackheads, and dark spots; can decrease the appearance of fine lines and make skin smoother; are a light peel with little or no down time, but are harsher than lactic acid</li>
<li>
<i>Lactic acid peels</i>: the best choice for hyperpigmentation, and good for first time users because it’s the gentlest option; fades dark marks and smoothes skin; can be used on all skin types, and better than glycolic acid for dry skin</li>
<li>
<i>TCA (trichloroacetic acid) peels</i>: stronger and more painful, will cause peeling, and requires 7-10 days of recovery; can improve shallow acne scars, stretch marks, skin tags, sun damage, fine lines and wrinkles</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-3-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=1564435" href="#/Image:Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-3-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Apply a Chemical Peel Step 3" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/11/Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-3-Version-3.jpg/aid1564435-v4-728px-Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-3-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_f81f6b5bee" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_f81f6b5bee')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Apply a Chemical Peel Step 3" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/11/Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-3-Version-3.jpg/aid1564435-v4-728px-Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-3-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Choose the lowest concentration for your first time.</b> If this is your first time using a chemical peel, use the lowest concentration of chemical possible. Gradually increase the strength as your skin gets used to it, if you want to. Choose a formula that contains this low percent of the active ingredient:<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 5" class="reference" id="_ref-5"><a href="#_note-5">[5]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>30% lactic acid</li>
<li>30% glycolic acid</li>
<li>8% TCA</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
<div class="wh_ad_inner step_ad" data-adsenseheight="90" data-adsensewidth="728" data-adunitpath="" data-aps-timeout="2000" data-apsload="1" data-channels="8161489800,3492389196" data-lateload="0" data-loaded="1" data-service="adsense" data-slot="7750426266" data-viewablerefresh="1">
<ins class="adsbygoogle" data-ad-client="ca-pub-9543332082073187" data-ad-slot="7750426266" style="display:inline-block;width:728px;height:90px;"></ins><script>(adsbygoogle = window.adsbygoogle || []).push({params: {google_ad_channel: '8161489800,3492389196'}});</script>
</div>
<div class="clearall adclear"></div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Preparing_for_Your_Peel_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock">Part <span>2</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Preparing_for_Your_Peel">Preparing for Your Peel</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_2">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-4-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=1564435" href="#/Image:Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-4-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Apply a Chemical Peel Step 4" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d3/Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-4-Version-3.jpg/aid1564435-v4-728px-Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-4-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_b93b1d5cb7" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_b93b1d5cb7')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Apply a Chemical Peel Step 4" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d3/Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-4-Version-3.jpg/aid1564435-v4-728px-Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-4-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Stop using tretinoin-based products for a week.</b> Stop using any products that contain tretinoin, like Retin-A or Differin, at least a week before your chemical peel. These products can irritate your skin, which could impact the outcome of your peel.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 6" class="reference" id="_ref-6"><a href="#_note-6">[6]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>For glycolic acid and lactic acid peels, discontinue there products for 3-4 days before and after your peel.</li>
<li>For TCA peels, stop using them for 5 days before and 10 days after your peel.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-5-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=1564435" href="#/Image:Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-5-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Apply a Chemical Peel Step 5" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f1/Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-5-Version-3.jpg/aid1564435-v4-728px-Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-5-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_62efcdd6dd" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_62efcdd6dd')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Apply a Chemical Peel Step 5" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f1/Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-5-Version-3.jpg/aid1564435-v4-728px-Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-5-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Gently exfoliate your face the day before your peel.</b> Perform a mild exfoliation treatment 24 hours prior to your treatment, using a gentle facial scrub. After washing your skin, apply a pH solution to prepare your skin for the peel.

</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-6-Version-3.jpg?ajax=true&aid=1564435" href="#/Image:Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-6-Version-3.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Apply a Chemical Peel Step 6" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/17/Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-6-Version-3.jpg/aid1564435-v4-728px-Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-6-Version-3.jpg" height="546" id="img_135a5b4070" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_135a5b4070')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Apply a Chemical Peel Step 6" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/17/Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-6-Version-3.jpg/aid1564435-v4-728px-Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-6-Version-3.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Do a spot test before applying your peel.</b> Apply a dab of the chemical peel to your forearm or to the area of skin below your ear at the hairline. Leave the solution on for at least a minute before washing it off. Check the patch test after 24 hours to make sure your skin doesn’t react negatively to the peel.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 7" class="reference" id="_ref-7"><a href="#_note-7">[7]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>If your skin looks normal around the test area, proceed with your chemical peel. If your skin is irritated, red, or tender, lower the concentration of the active ingredient (glycolic, lactic or trichloroacetic acid) in the peel solution and try another test. If you get to the lowest concentration of chemicals and still see a reaction, do not do the chemical peel.</li>
<li>If you have any signs of an allergic reaction, like itching or hives, do not use the chemical peel.</li>
<li>Apply the peel with a Q-tip – using your fingers may make your fingers peel.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
<div class="wh_ad_inner step_ad" data-adsenseheight="90" data-adsensewidth="728" data-adunitpath="" data-aps-timeout="2000" data-apsload="1" data-channels="8161489800,3492389196" data-lateload="0" data-loaded="1" data-service="adsense" data-slot="7750426266" data-viewablerefresh="1">
<ins class="adsbygoogle" data-ad-client="ca-pub-9543332082073187" data-ad-slot="7750426266" style="display:inline-block;width:728px;height:90px;"></ins><script>(adsbygoogle = window.adsbygoogle || []).push({params: {google_ad_channel: '8161489800,3492389196'}});</script>
</div>
<div class="clearall adclear"></div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Using_the_Chemical_Peel_Appropriately_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock">Part <span>3</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Using_the_Chemical_Peel_Appropriately">Using the Chemical Peel Appropriately</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_3">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-7.jpg?ajax=true&aid=1564435" href="#/Image:Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-7.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Apply a Chemical Peel Step 7" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3c/Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-7.jpg/aid1564435-v4-728px-Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-7.jpg" height="546" id="img_ce88d41621" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_ce88d41621')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Apply a Chemical Peel Step 7" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3c/Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-7.jpg/aid1564435-v4-728px-Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-7.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Cleanse your face before applying the chemical peel solution.</b> Use water and a soap-free cleanser to wash your face.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 8" class="reference" id="_ref-8"><a href="#_note-8">[8]</a></sup> Finish with an application of a mild astringent such as witch hazel, or the prep solution that came with your chemical peel kit. Let the prep solution dry before you apply your peel.

</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-8.jpg?ajax=true&aid=1564435" href="#/Image:Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-8.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Apply a Chemical Peel Step 8" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0f/Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-8.jpg/aid1564435-v4-728px-Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-8.jpg" height="546" id="img_fb16991df5" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_fb16991df5')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Apply a Chemical Peel Step 8" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0f/Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-8.jpg/aid1564435-v4-728px-Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-8.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Protect sensitive areas with petroleum jelly.</b> Avoid applying the peel to sensitive areas of your skin such as around your eyes, your nostrils, and the corners of your lips. Before applying your peel, dab some petroleum jelly onto these areas to help protect them from the acid.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 9" class="reference" id="_ref-9"><a href="#_note-9">[9]</a></sup>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-9.jpg?ajax=true&aid=1564435" href="#/Image:Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-9.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Apply a Chemical Peel Step 9" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/00/Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-9.jpg/aid1564435-v4-728px-Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-9.jpg" height="546" id="img_93d02d31dc" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_93d02d31dc')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Apply a Chemical Peel Step 9" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/00/Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-9.jpg/aid1564435-v4-728px-Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-9.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Apply an even coat of the chemical peel solution to your skin.</b> Use a cotton ball, cotton swab, small brush or Q-tip for the application process. Start with the less sensitive areas of skin around the forehead, chin and cheeks. Continue to apply the chemical peel to the lower eyelids, nose and neck area.

<ul>
<li>Make sure the solution is applied evenly, or your chemical peel results will be inconsistent.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-10.jpg?ajax=true&aid=1564435" href="#/Image:Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-10.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Apply a Chemical Peel Step 10" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/49/Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-10.jpg/aid1564435-v4-728px-Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-10.jpg" height="546" id="img_54ae15ca61" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_54ae15ca61')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Apply a Chemical Peel Step 10" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/49/Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-10.jpg/aid1564435-v4-728px-Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-10.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Leave the peel on for the recommended amount of time or less.</b> Most chemical peel kits recommend no more than 1 to 2 minutes, depending on the type of peel and the concentration of chemicals in the solution. Read the label before applying your peel so you know how long to wait. If your skin starts turning pink, wash the peel off.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 10" class="reference" id="_ref-10"><a href="#_note-10">[10]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Watch your skin for signs of irritation. While some burning is normal, if your skin begins to sting intensely, remove the peel solution right away.</li>
<li>Use the spot test to determine how long to leave your peel on your face. If your spot test burns after two minutes, only apply it to your face for one minute.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-11.jpg?ajax=true&aid=1564435" href="#/Image:Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-11.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Apply a Chemical Peel Step 11" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/80/Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-11.jpg/aid1564435-v4-728px-Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-11.jpg" height="546" id="img_0b66e4bdf9" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_0b66e4bdf9')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Apply a Chemical Peel Step 11" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/80/Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-11.jpg/aid1564435-v4-728px-Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-11.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 5" class="step_num">5</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_5"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Remove the peel and apply a neutralizing solution.</b> Many kits come with a neutralizing solution that stops the work of the chemicals so they do not continue to burn your skin. If your kit does not come with a neutralizer, that means your peel is designed to stop working as soon as it is washed off, and an additional solution is not needed.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 11" class="reference" id="_ref-11"><a href="#_note-11">[11]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Read the instructions in your chemical peel kit to confirm if a neutralizer is needed.</li>
<li>To be safe, you can prepare your own mixture of water and baking soda to use as a neutralizer, in case the peel becomes too irritating. Mix this into a paste and apply it to your skin after you wash off your peel, if needed.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-12.jpg?ajax=true&aid=1564435" href="#/Image:Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-12.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Apply a Chemical Peel Step 12" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/01/Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-12.jpg/aid1564435-v4-728px-Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-12.jpg" height="546" id="img_fbddd1b1b6" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_fbddd1b1b6')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Apply a Chemical Peel Step 12" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/01/Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-12.jpg/aid1564435-v4-728px-Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-12.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 6" class="step_num">6</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_6"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Use a stronger peel only once you’re used to it.</b> If your peel goes well and you want to use a stronger peel in the future, you have some options. Always do a spot test before applying your full peel. Try one of these options to strengthen your peel:<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 12" class="reference" id="_ref-12"><a href="#_note-12">[12]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Use a formula with a higher percentage of the active ingredient</li>
<li>Layer your peels – apply a layer, wait 5 minutes, and apply another layer</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
<div class="wh_ad_inner step_ad" data-adsenseheight="90" data-adsensewidth="728" data-adunitpath="" data-aps-timeout="2000" data-apsload="1" data-channels="8161489800,3492389196" data-lateload="0" data-loaded="1" data-service="adsense" data-slot="7750426266" data-viewablerefresh="1">
<ins class="adsbygoogle" data-ad-client="ca-pub-9543332082073187" data-ad-slot="7750426266" style="display:inline-block;width:728px;height:90px;"></ins><script>(adsbygoogle = window.adsbygoogle || []).push({params: {google_ad_channel: '8161489800,3492389196'}});</script>
</div>
<div class="clearall adclear"></div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Performing_After-Care_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock">Part <span>4</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Performing_After-Care">Performing After-Care</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_4">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-13.jpg?ajax=true&aid=1564435" href="#/Image:Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-13.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Apply a Chemical Peel Step 13" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1c/Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-13.jpg/aid1564435-v4-728px-Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-13.jpg" height="546" id="img_2517a06bf8" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_2517a06bf8')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Apply a Chemical Peel Step 13" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1c/Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-13.jpg/aid1564435-v4-728px-Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-13.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_4_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Apply moisturizer to your face right after your peel.</b> Liberally apply some facial moisturizer to your skin after you remove your chemical peel. Use your normal face moisturizer, or get a thoroughly hydrating solution for this purpose. Re-apply this 10-20 times throughout the day – don’t let your skin dry out.

<ul>
<li>If you peel, don’t pick at it! Let your skin heal naturally or you might damage it. Dab Vaseline or Aquaphor over areas that are very dry.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-14.jpg?ajax=true&aid=1564435" href="#/Image:Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-14.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Apply a Chemical Peel Step 14" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/45/Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-14.jpg/aid1564435-v4-728px-Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-14.jpg" height="546" id="img_208ceb9594" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_208ceb9594')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Apply a Chemical Peel Step 14" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/45/Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-14.jpg/aid1564435-v4-728px-Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-14.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_4_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Ease redness with cooling products.</b> It’s normal for your skin to be red and to sting after your peel. This may only last a few hours, or the whole day. Soothe redness by wrapping a cold wet towel over your face. You can also try aloe vera gel, a cooling mask, ice packs, or putting a cool mist humidifier in your room.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 13" class="reference" id="_ref-13"><a href="#_note-13">[13]</a></sup>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-15.jpg?ajax=true&aid=1564435" href="#/Image:Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-15.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Apply a Chemical Peel Step 15" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/79/Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-15.jpg/aid1564435-v4-728px-Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-15.jpg" height="546" id="img_4062bf9034" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_4062bf9034')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Apply a Chemical Peel Step 15" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/79/Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-15.jpg/aid1564435-v4-728px-Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-15.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_4_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Protect your face from the sun.</b> Your skin will be sensitive and tender after your chemical peel. Stay out of the sun until this subsides. If you do go in the sun, wear sunscreen on your face.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 14" class="reference" id="_ref-14"><a href="#_note-14">[14]</a></sup>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-16.jpg?ajax=true&aid=1564435" href="#/Image:Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-16.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Apply a Chemical Peel Step 16" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/bf/Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-16.jpg/aid1564435-v4-728px-Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-16.jpg" height="546" id="img_c616a1aa0c" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_c616a1aa0c')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Apply a Chemical Peel Step 16" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/bf/Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-16.jpg/aid1564435-v4-728px-Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-16.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_4_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Wash your face gently twice a day.</b> Rinse your face twice a day with soap-less cleanser or water, for 10-30 seconds. Rinse your face with lukewarm water by splashing water onto your face over the sink. Pat your skin dry with a clean towel. Do NOT rub your skin.

</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-17.jpg?ajax=true&aid=1564435" href="#/Image:Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-17.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Apply a Chemical Peel Step 17" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/6a/Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-17.jpg/aid1564435-v4-728px-Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-17.jpg" height="546" id="img_dcd4acf299" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_dcd4acf299')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Apply a Chemical Peel Step 17" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/6a/Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-17.jpg/aid1564435-v4-728px-Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-17.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 5" class="step_num">5</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_4_5"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Sleep on your back.</b> Avoid pressing your face into anything or rubbing your face until the skin heals. Sleep on your back so you don’t rub your cheek or forehead on the pillow.

</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage final_li">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-18.jpg?ajax=true&aid=1564435" href="#/Image:Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-18.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Apply a Chemical Peel Step 18" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0c/Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-18.jpg/aid1564435-v4-728px-Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-18.jpg" height="546" id="img_9e03ece2d0" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_9e03ece2d0')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Apply a Chemical Peel Step 18" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0c/Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-18.jpg/aid1564435-v4-728px-Apply-a-Chemical-Peel-Step-18.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 6" class="step_num">6</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_4_6"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">See your doctor if your skin crusts or oozes.</b> See your doctor right away if you have signs of an infection. This can be an area of skin that looks especially crusty and tender, yellow, or that oozes fluid.

</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>

<ins class="adsbygoogle" data-ad-client="ca-pub-9543332082073187" data-ad-slot="7750426266" style="display:inline-block;width:728px;height:90px;"></ins><script>(adsbygoogle = window.adsbygoogle || []).push({params: {google_ad_channel: '8161489800,3492389196'}});</script>
</div>
<div class="clearall adclear"></div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="qa section sticky qa_show_unanswered_questions" data-aid="1564435" data-few_contribs="1" data-search_enabled="0">
<h2>
<div class="altblock"></div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="qa_headline">Community Q&A</span>
</h2>
<div class="section_text" id="qa">
<div id="qa_answered_questions_container">
<div id="qa_aq_search_container">

<ul class="qa_questions qa_aqs qa_waittheresmore" id="qa_article_questions">
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="262737" data-caid="263610" data-cqid="262754" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="1559788" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="0" data-votes_up="3">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">Which chemical peel will work for dark circles under my eyes? </div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">The skin around your eyes is very sensitive and delicate, and getting chemicals in your eyes is quite dangerous - you're better off not attempting to use a chemical peel near your eyes. Try more natural remedies like getting more sleep, treating any allergies like hay fever you might have, and wearing sunscreen on your face.</div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>

<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">No</a>
</div>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_buttons">
<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box" href="#">Not Helpful <span>0</span></a>
<a class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box" href="#">Helpful <span>3</span></a>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="262729" data-caid="263602" data-cqid="262746" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="1634835" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="0" data-votes_up="2">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">What can I do for milia on my face?</div>

<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">If you have serious skin problems, it's best to consult a dermatologist. They can help you understand what is causing your condition, and make suggestions about treatment. You can try a very gentle chemical peel, but professional help is the safest and most effective way to get results.</div>

<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>

</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="262727" data-caid="263600" data-cqid="262744" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="1378235" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="0" data-votes_up="2">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">Do I apply the solution between the eyebrow and the eyelid?</div>
<div class="qa_answers">
<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">It's best not to - the skin of your eyelid is very delicate and sensitive, and you'd be risking getting the chemical solution in your eye. Stay away from sensitive areas like around your eyes, the undersides of your nostrils (the bridge of your nose is okay), and the corners of your lips.</div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
<span class="wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg">Thanks!</span>
<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">

<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary" href="#">No</a>
</div>

<a class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box" href="#">Not Helpful <span>0</span></a>

</div>

<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="74204" data-caid="75077" data-cqid="74221" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="507718" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="2" data-votes_up="3">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">I have two big scars on my face. Will a chemical peel diminish their appearance?</div>

<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">Yes, it most likely will over time. However, be careful if you are on the darker side, as this might lead to hyperpigmentation.</div>
<div class="qa_answer_footer">
<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">

<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="262726" data-caid="263599" data-cqid="262743" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="1456659" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="0" data-votes_up="1">
<div class="qa_divider"></div>
<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">I have a post inflammatory pigmentation scar on my upper lip which happened due to a chemical burn from hair removal cream. Can this help? Or make it worse?</div>

<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">In this case, it's best to consult a dermatologist. You may have skin that reacts negatively to chemical treatments, and using a chemical peel may make it worse. Talk to your doctor about the risks and benefits of using a chemical peel for you.</div>

</div>

<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>

</div>

<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="418541" data-caid="419414" data-cqid="418558" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="955789" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="0" data-votes_up="0">

<div class="qa_li_container">
<div class="qa_question_tab">Question</div>
<div class="qa_q_txt question">If I have very dry skin, can I apply glycolic?</div>

<div class="qa_user_area">
<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box"></div>
<div class="qa_badge"></div>
<div class="qa_person_circle"></div>
<div class="qa_answerer_info">
<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="qa_answer answer">Yes, but if you find that it irritates your skin or dries it out more, avoid applying it in the future.</div>

<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="419366" data-caid="420239" data-cqid="419383" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="910154" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="0" data-votes_up="0">

<div class="section tips sticky">
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Tips">Tips</span></h2>
<div class="section_text" id="tips">
<ul>
<li>You will probably need to do multiple chemical peels before you start to see results.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 15" class="reference" id="_ref-15"><a href="#_note-15">[15]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>TCA peels are especially harsh and will leave your skin red and sensitive for longer than lactic acid or glycolic acid peels. Use after-care protocol for as long as your skin is irritated – especially moisturizing and staying out of the sun.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 16" class="reference" id="_ref-16"><a href="#_note-16">[16]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="section warnings sticky">
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Warnings">Warnings</span></h2>
<div class="section_text" id="warnings">
<ul>
<li>Do not leave a chemical peel on your face for too long, or skin damage and burning can result. Watch your skin and the clock to ensure you get the full benefits of your peel without any negative side effects.</li>
<li>This is a potentially dangerous procedure that you should get done professionally, if possible. Keep it away from children.</li>
<li>Chemical peels work best for people with light skin. They may cause darkening or lightening of the skin in darker-skinned individuals.</li>
<li>Do NOT get the chemical peel in your eyes.</li>
<li>Do a gentle peel like 30% glycolic acid or lactic acid every 2-3 weeks at the MOST. Only do a deeper peel like TCA once a month at the most.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 17" class="reference" id="_ref-17"><a href="#_note-17">[17]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>

        "width": 1200,

    "author": {

            "@type": "ImageObject",

            "width": 326,
            "height": 60
        },
        "sameAs": [
            "https:\/\/www.facebook.com\/wikiHow\/",
            "https:\/\/twitter.com\/wikiHow",
            "https:\/\/www.instagram.com\/wikihow\/",

            "https:\/\/www.youtube.com\/user\/WikiHow"
        ]
    },
    "step": [
        {
            "@type": "HowToSection",
            "name": "Selecting Your Chemical Peel",
            "position": 1,
            "itemListElement": [
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 1,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Buy from a reputable company with good reviews. If possible, get a chemical peel kit from a spa or dermatologist\u2019s office. If you shop online, be sure to check user reviews to see what customers are saying. Only buy a chemical peel from a reputable company with excellent user reviews.[2]\nChoose a product made in an FDA-regulated lab that is certified to be 99% pure or better.[3]\nMake sure the product contains a phone number for customer service. You should be able to call and ask questions if you need to."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 2,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Select the type of peel based on your needs. Different chemical peels are better for different needs and skin types. Choose the right peel for you:[4]\n\nGlycolic acid peels: improve acne, blackheads, and dark spots; can decrease the appearance of fine lines and make skin smoother; are a light peel with little or no down time, but are harsher than lactic acid\n\nLactic acid peels: the best choice for hyperpigmentation, and good for first time users because it\u2019s the gentlest option; fades dark marks and smoothes skin; can be used on all skin types, and better than glycolic acid for dry skin\n\nTCA (trichloroacetic acid) peels: stronger and more painful, will cause peeling, and requires 7-10 days of recovery; can improve shallow acne scars, stretch marks, skin tags, sun damage, fine lines and wrinkles"
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 3,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Choose the lowest concentration for your first time. If this is your first time using a chemical peel, use the lowest concentration of chemical possible. Gradually increase the strength as your skin gets used to it, if you want to. Choose a formula that contains this low percent of the active ingredient:[5]\n30% lactic acid\n30% glycolic acid\n8% TCA"
                    }
                }
            ]
        },
        {
            "@type": "HowToSection",
            "name": "Preparing for Your Peel",
            "position": 2,
            "itemListElement": [
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 1,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Stop using tretinoin-based products for a week. Stop using any products that contain tretinoin, like Retin-A or Differin, at least a week before your chemical peel. These products can irritate your skin, which could impact the outcome of your peel.[6]\nFor glycolic acid and lactic acid peels, discontinue there products for 3-4 days before and after your peel.\nFor TCA peels, stop using them for 5 days before and 10 days after your peel."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 2,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Gently exfoliate your face the day before your peel. Perform a mild exfoliation treatment 24 hours prior to your treatment, using a gentle facial scrub. After washing your skin, apply a pH solution to prepare your skin for the peel."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 3,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Do a spot test before applying your peel. Apply a dab of the chemical peel to your forearm or to the area of skin below your ear at the hairline. Leave the solution on for at least a minute before washing it off. Check the patch test after 24 hours to make sure your skin doesn\u2019t react negatively to the peel.[7]\nIf your skin looks normal around the test area, proceed with your chemical peel. If your skin is irritated, red, or tender, lower the concentration of the active ingredient (glycolic, lactic or trichloroacetic acid) in the peel solution and try another test. If you get to the lowest concentration of chemicals and still see a reaction, do not do the chemical peel.\nIf you have any signs of an allergic reaction, like itching or hives, do not use the chemical peel.\nApply the peel with a Q-tip \u2013 using your fingers may make your fingers peel."
                    }
                }
            ]
        },
        {
            "@type": "HowToSection",
            "name": "Using the Chemical Peel Appropriately",
            "position": 3,
            "itemListElement": [
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 1,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Cleanse your face before applying the chemical peel solution. Use water and a soap-free cleanser to wash your face.[8] Finish with an application of a mild astringent such as witch hazel, or the prep solution that came with your chemical peel kit. Let the prep solution dry before you apply your peel."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 2,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Protect sensitive areas with petroleum jelly. Avoid applying the peel to sensitive areas of your skin such as around your eyes, your nostrils, and the corners of your lips. Before applying your peel, dab some petroleum jelly onto these areas to help protect them from the acid.[9]"
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 3,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Apply an even coat of the chemical peel solution to your skin. Use a cotton ball, cotton swab, small brush or Q-tip for the application process. Start with the less sensitive areas of skin around the forehead, chin and cheeks. Continue to apply the chemical peel to the lower eyelids, nose and neck area.\n\nMake sure the solution is applied evenly, or your chemical peel results will be inconsistent."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 4,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Leave the peel on for the recommended amount of time or less. Most chemical peel kits recommend no more than 1 to 2 minutes, depending on the type of peel and the concentration of chemicals in the solution. Read the label before applying your peel so you know how long to wait. If your skin starts turning pink, wash the peel off.[10]\nWatch your skin for signs of irritation. While some burning is normal, if your skin begins to sting intensely, remove the peel solution right away.\nUse the spot test to determine how long to leave your peel on your face. If your spot test burns after two minutes, only apply it to your face for one minute."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 5,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Remove the peel and apply a neutralizing solution. Many kits come with a neutralizing solution that stops the work of the chemicals so they do not continue to burn your skin. If your kit does not come with a neutralizer, that means your peel is designed to stop working as soon as it is washed off, and an additional solution is not needed.[11]\nRead the instructions in your chemical peel kit to confirm if a neutralizer is needed.\nTo be safe, you can prepare your own mixture of water and baking soda to use as a neutralizer, in case the peel becomes too irritating. Mix this into a paste and apply it to your skin after you wash off your peel, if needed."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 6,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Use a stronger peel only once you\u2019re used to it. If your peel goes well and you want to use a stronger peel in the future, you have some options. Always do a spot test before applying your full peel. content_html:
Buy from a reputable company with good reviews. If possible, get a chemical peel kit from a spa or dermatologist’s office. If you shop online, be sure to check user reviews to see what customers are saying. Only buy a chemical peel from a reputable company with excellent user reviews.[2]
  • Choose a product made in an FDA-regulated lab that is certified to be 99% pure or better.[3]
  • Make sure the product contains a phone number for customer service. You should be able to call and ask questions if you need to.
Select the type of peel based on your needs. Different chemical peels are better for different needs and skin types. Choose the right peel for you:[4]
  • Glycolic acid peels: improve acne, blackheads, and dark spots; can decrease the appearance of fine lines and make skin smoother; are a light peel with little or no down time, but are harsher than lactic acid
  • Lactic acid peels: the best choice for hyperpigmentation, and good for first time users because it’s the gentlest option; fades dark marks and smoothes skin; can be used on all skin types, and better than glycolic acid for dry skin
  • TCA (trichloroacetic acid) peels: stronger and more painful, will cause peeling, and requires 7-10 days of recovery; can improve shallow acne scars, stretch marks, skin tags, sun damage, fine lines and wrinkles
Choose the lowest concentration for your first time. If this is your first time using a chemical peel, use the lowest concentration of chemical possible. Gradually increase the strength as your skin gets used to it, if you want to. Choose a formula that contains this low percent of the active ingredient:[5]
  • 30% lactic acid
  • 30% glycolic acid
  • 8% TCA
Stop using tretinoin-based products for a week. Stop using any products that contain tretinoin, like Retin-A or Differin, at least a week before your chemical peel. These products can irritate your skin, which could impact the outcome of your peel.[6]
  • For glycolic acid and lactic acid peels, discontinue there products for 3-4 days before and after your peel.
  • For TCA peels, stop using them for 5 days before and 10 days after your peel.
Gently exfoliate your face the day before your peel. Perform a mild exfoliation treatment 24 hours prior to your treatment, using a gentle facial scrub. After washing your skin, apply a pH solution to prepare your skin for the peel.
Do a spot test before applying your peel. Apply a dab of the chemical peel to your forearm or to the area of skin below your ear at the hairline. Leave the solution on for at least a minute before washing it off. Check the patch test after 24 hours to make sure your skin doesn’t react negatively to the peel.[7]
  • If your skin looks normal around the test area, proceed with your chemical peel. If your skin is irritated, red, or tender, lower the concentration of the active ingredient (glycolic, lactic or trichloroacetic acid) in the peel solution and try another test. If you get to the lowest concentration of chemicals and still see a reaction, do not do the chemical peel.
  • If you have any signs of an allergic reaction, like itching or hives, do not use the chemical peel.
  • Apply the peel with a Q-tip – using your fingers may make your fingers peel.
Cleanse your face before applying the chemical peel solution. Use water and a soap-free cleanser to wash your face.[8] Finish with an application of a mild astringent such as witch hazel, or the prep solution that came with your chemical peel kit. Let the prep solution dry before you apply your peel.
Protect sensitive areas with petroleum jelly. Avoid applying the peel to sensitive areas of your skin such as around your eyes, your nostrils, and the corners of your lips. Before applying your peel, dab some petroleum jelly onto these areas to help protect them from the acid.[9]
Apply an even coat of the chemical peel solution to your skin. Use a cotton ball, cotton swab, small brush or Q-tip for the application process. Start with the less sensitive areas of skin around the forehead, chin and cheeks. Continue to apply the chemical peel to the lower eyelids, nose and neck area.
  • Make sure the solution is applied evenly, or your chemical peel results will be inconsistent.
Leave the peel on for the recommended amount of time or less. Most chemical peel kits recommend no more than 1 to 2 minutes, depending on the type of peel and the concentration of chemicals in the solution. Read the label before applying your peel so you know how long to wait. If your skin starts turning pink, wash the peel off.[10]
  • Watch your skin for signs of irritation. While some burning is normal, if your skin begins to sting intensely, remove the peel solution right away.
  • Use the spot test to determine how long to leave your peel on your face. If your spot test burns after two minutes, only apply it to your face for one minute.
Remove the peel and apply a neutralizing solution. Many kits come with a neutralizing solution that stops the work of the chemicals so they do not continue to burn your skin. If your kit does not come with a neutralizer, that means your peel is designed to stop working as soon as it is washed off, and an additional solution is not needed.[11]
  • Read the instructions in your chemical peel kit to confirm if a neutralizer is needed.
  • To be safe, you can prepare your own mixture of water and baking soda to use as a neutralizer, in case the peel becomes too irritating. Mix this into a paste and apply it to your skin after you wash off your peel, if needed.
Use a stronger peel only once you’re used to it. If your peel goes well and you want to use a stronger peel in the future, you have some options. Always do a spot test before applying your full peel. Try one of these options to strengthen your peel:[12]
  • Use a formula with a higher percentage of the active ingredient
  • Layer your peels – apply a layer, wait 5 minutes, and apply another layer
Apply moisturizer to your face right after your peel. Liberally apply some facial moisturizer to your skin after you remove your chemical peel. Use your normal face moisturizer, or get a thoroughly hydrating solution for this purpose. Re-apply this 10-20 times throughout the day – don’t let your skin dry out.
  • If you peel, don’t pick at it! Let your skin heal naturally or you might damage it. Dab Vaseline or Aquaphor over areas that are very dry.
Ease redness with cooling products. It’s normal for your skin to be red and to sting after your peel. This may only last a few hours, or the whole day. Soothe redness by wrapping a cold wet towel over your face. You can also try aloe vera gel, a cooling mask, ice packs, or putting a cool mist humidifier in your room.[13]
Protect your face from the sun. Your skin will be sensitive and tender after your chemical peel. Stay out of the sun until this subsides. If you do go in the sun, wear sunscreen on your face.[14]
Wash your face gently twice a day. Rinse your face twice a day with soap-less cleanser or water, for 10-30 seconds. Rinse your face with lukewarm water by splashing water onto your face over the sink. Pat your skin dry with a clean towel. Do NOT rub your skin.
Sleep on your back. Avoid pressing your face into anything or rubbing your face until the skin heals. Sleep on your back so you don’t rub your cheek or forehead on the pillow.
See your doctor if your skin crusts or oozes. See your doctor right away if you have signs of an infection. This can be an area of skin that looks especially crusty and tender, yellow, or that oozes fluid.
